questions.question: What are the 4 steps when having an R U OK? conversation

choices.answer: Listen, encourage actions, check in, ask
Ask, listen, encourage action, check in
Ask, check in, listen, encourage action
Encourage action, ask, listen, check in

questions.question: Before you ask a friend R U OK?

choices.answer: Pick a comfortable and private space to talk.
Tell the person that everyone is talking about how "weird" they're acting.
Say you've noticed some changes in them recently.
Pick a time where you can talk so you don't have to rush.

questions.question: Good listening skills to use when asking R U OK? include;

choices.answer: Giving the person time to open up and share.
Point out they are wrong and being ridiculous.
Talk over the person and interrupt them when you have something to say.
Use active listening skills, eg. head nodding and asking questions.

questions.question: If you have asked R U OK & the person doesn't want to talk or say they're fine but you don't think this is true, you can

choices.answer: Push them for more information.
Start arguing with them and say you don't believe them.
Tell them you are still concerned about them and care about them.
Let them know you are there if they want to have a chat.

questions.question: A great way to offer support is to ask the person a question like "How can I help you right now"?

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: If the person does need further support, you can encourage them to reach out to;

choices.answer: Family and close friends
A trusted adult, eg. Teacher, school wellbeing team.
A health and wellbeing professional.
The family pet.

questions.question: If someone has felt really low for more than 2 weeks or is unsafe or feeling suicidal, it is important they seek help

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: It can sometimes take a while before someone feels ready to see a professional about how they are feeling

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: After the R U OK? conversation, it is beneficial to;

choices.answer: Pretend the conversation never happened.
Let them know you've been thinking about them.
Ignore any messages or phone calls from the person.
Check in and ask how they're going after the initial conversation.

questions.question: What services can assist someone who is struggling?

choices.answer: Kids helpline
Headspace
eHeadspace
Reach Out
